body:
# redis

A pure-Crystal implementation of the Redis protocol

## Installation

1. Add the dependency to your `shard.yml`:

   ```yaml
   dependencies:
     redis:
       github: jgaskins/redis
   ```

   Note that this shard currently depends on a fork of `crystal-db` for its connection pool. I'm in the process of getting those changes merged upstream so it can depend on the mainline implementation of that shard.

2. Run `shards`

## Usage

```crystal
require "redis"

redis = Redis::Client.new # Defaults to `localhost` port 6379

redis.set "foo", "bar"
redis.get "foo" # => "bar"

redis.incr "counter" # => 1
redis.incr "counter" # => 2
redis.decr "counter" # => 1

redis.del "foo", "counter" # => 2
```

To use a Redis server that isn't at `localhost:6379`, pass a `URI` to the client. For example, if you store it in your shell environment:

```crystal
redis = Redis::Client.new(URI.parse(ENV["REDIS_URL"]))
```

To connect via SSL, make sure you use the `rediss://` URL scheme. If your Redis server requires a password or uses a different database slot than `0`, make sure you include them in the URL:

```crystal
redis = Redis::Client.new(URI.parse("rediss://:my_password@example.com/3"))
```

### Connection Pool

The `Redis::Client` maintains its own connection pool, so there is no need to run your own within your application. When you execute a command on the `Redis::Client`, it is automatically being executed against a connection. When you execute a pipeline or transaction with `multi`, all commands within that block will automatically be routed to the same connection.

## Development

Make sure you have a Redis or KeyDB server running locally on port 6379.

## Contributing

1. Fork it (<https://github.com/jgaskins/redis/fork>)
2. Create your feature branch (`git checkout -b my-new-feature`)
3. Commit your changes (`git commit -am 'Add some feature'`)
4. Push to the branch (`git push origin my-new-feature`)
5. Create a new Pull Request

## Contributors

- [Jamie Gaskins](https://github.com/jgaskins) - creator and maintainer

types.name: Client
types.doc:
The Redis client is the expected entrypoint for this shard. By default, it will connect to localhost:6379, but you can also supply a `URI` to connect to an arbitrary Redis server. SSL, password authentication, and DB selection are all supported.

```
# Connects to localhost:6379
redis = Redis::Client.new

# Connects to a server at "redis.example.com" on port 6000 over a TLS
# connection, authenticates with the password "password", and uses DB 3
redis = Redis::Client.new(URI.parse("rediss://:password@redis.example.com:6000/3"))

# Connects to a server at the URL in `ENV["REDIS_URL"]`
redis = Redis::Client.from_env("REDIS_URL")
```
types.summary: The Redis client is the expected entrypoint for this shard.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
The client holds a pool of connections that expands and contracts as
needed.
constructors.summary: The client holds a pool of connections that expands and contracts as needed.

macros.name: method_missing
macros.doc:
All Redis commands invoked on the client check out a connection from the
connection pool, invoke the command on that connection, and then check the
connection back into the pool.

```
redis = Redis::Client.new
```
macros.summary: All Redis commands invoked on the client check out a connection from the connection pool, invoke the command on that connection, and then check the connection back into the pool.

types.name: Commands
types.doc:
All Redis commands are defined in this module. Any paradigm that needs to
use these commands simply overrides `run`, which takes a single `command`
object, which must be an `Enumerable`.

TODO: Add more Redis commands from https://redis.io/commands
types.summary: All Redis commands are defined in this module.

instance_methods.name: brpop
instance_methods.doc:
Remove and return an element from the end of the given list. If the list
is empty or the key does not exist, this method waits the specified amount
of time for an element to be added to it by another connection. If the
element *is* added by another connection within that amount of time, this
method will return it immediately. If it *is not*, then this method returns
`nil`.

```
redis.lpush "foo", "hello"
redis.rpop "foo" # => "hello"
redis.rpop "foo" # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Remove and return an element from the end of the given list.

instance_methods.name: brpop
instance_methods.doc:
Remove and return an element from the end of the given list. If the list
is empty or the key does not exist, this method waits the specified number
of seconds for an element to be added to it by another connection. If the
element *is* added by another connection within that number of seconds,
this method will return it immediately. If it *is not*, then this method
returns `nil`.

```
redis.lpush "foo", "hello"
redis.rpop "foo" # => "hello"
redis.rpop "foo" # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Remove and return an element from the end of the given list.

def.name: brpop
def.body:
if timeout == timeout.to_i
  timeout = timeout.to_i
end
brpop(*keys, timeout: timeout.to_s)

instance_methods.name: brpop
instance_methods.doc:
Remove and return an element from the end of the given list. If the list
is empty or the key does not exist, this method waits the specified number
of seconds for an element to be added to it by another connection. If the
element *is* added by another connection within that number of seconds,
this method will return it immediately. If it *is not*, then this method
returns `nil`.

```
redis.lpush "foo", "hello"
redis.rpop "foo" # => "hello"
redis.rpop "foo" # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Remove and return an element from the end of the given list.

instance_methods.name: decr
instance_methods.doc:
Atomically decrement and return the integer value for the specified key,
creating it if it does not exist

```
redis.del "counter"
redis.decr "counter" # => -1
```
instance_methods.summary: Atomically decrement and return the integer value for the specified key, creating it if it does not exist

instance_methods.name: decrby
instance_methods.doc:
Atomically decrement and return the integer value for the specified key by
the specified amount, creating it if it does not exist

```
redis.del "counter"
redis.decrby "counter", 2 # => -2
```
instance_methods.summary: Atomically decrement and return the integer value for the specified key by the specified amount, creating it if it does not exist

instance_methods.name: del
instance_methods.doc:
Delete all specified keys and return the number of keys deleted.

```
redis.set "foo"
redis.del "foo", "bar" # => 1
redis.del "foo", "bar" # => 0
```
instance_methods.summary: Delete all specified keys and return the number of keys deleted.

instance_methods.name: get
instance_methods.doc:
Get the value for the specified key

```
redis.set "foo", "bar"
redis.get("foo") # => "bar"
```
instance_methods.summary: Get the value for the specified key

instance_methods.name: incr
instance_methods.doc:
Atomically increment and return the integer value for the specified key,
creating it if it does not exist

```
redis.del "counter"
redis.incr "counter" # => 1
```
instance_methods.summary: Atomically increment and return the integer value for the specified key, creating it if it does not exist

instance_methods.name: incrby
instance_methods.doc:
Atomically increment and return the integer value for the specified key by
the specified amount, creating it if it does not exist

```
redis.del "counter"
redis.incrby "counter", 2 # => 2
```
instance_methods.summary: Atomically increment and return the integer value for the specified key by the specified amount, creating it if it does not exist

instance_methods.name: keys
instance_methods.doc:
Get the keys whose names follow the specified glob pattern. If a pattern
is not specified, it will return all keys by default. Be careful when
using this command on Redis servers with a lot of traffic and millions
of keys.

```
redis.keys # => ["foo", "bar", "baz"]
redis.keys("f*") # => ["foo"]
redis.keys("b*") # => ["bar", "baz"]
```
instance_methods.summary: Get the keys whose names follow the specified glob pattern.

instance_methods.name: lpush
instance_methods.doc:
Insert an item at the beginning of a list, returning the number of items
in the list after the insert.

```
redis.del "my-list" # Delete so we know it's empty
redis.lpush "my-list", "foo", "bar" # => 2
redis.lpush "my-list", "foo", "bar" # => 4
```
instance_methods.summary: Insert an item at the beginning of a list, returning the number of items in the list after the insert.

instance_methods.name: rpop
instance_methods.doc:
Remove and return an element from the end of the given list. If the list
is empty or the key does not exist, this method returns `nil`

```
redis.lpush "foo", "hello"
redis.rpop "foo" # => "hello"
redis.rpop "foo" # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Remove and return an element from the end of the given list.

instance_methods.name: rpoplpush
instance_methods.doc:
Atomically remove an item from the end of a list and insert it at the
beginning of another. Returns that list item. If the first list is empty,
nothing happens and this method returns `nil`.

```
redis.del "foo"
redis.lpush "foo", "hello", "world"
redis.rpoplpush "foo", "bar" # => "hello"
redis.rpoplpush "foo", "bar" # => "world"
redis.rpoplpush "foo", "bar" # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Atomically remove an item from the end of a list and insert it at the beginning of another.

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.doc:
Execute the given command and return the result from the server. Commands
must be an `Enumerable` and its `size` method must be re-entrant.

```
run({"set", "foo", "bar"})
```
instance_methods.summary: Execute the given command and return the result from the server.

instance_methods.name: set
instance_methods.doc:
Set a given key to a given value, optionally specifying time-to-live (TTL).

- `ex`: TTL in seconds (mnemonic: "ex" = "expiration")
- `px`: TTL in milliseconds
- `nx`: Only set this key if it does not exist (mnemonic: "nx" = it does "not exist")
- `xx`: only set this key if it does exist (mnemonic: "xx" = it "exists exists" â€” look, I don't make the rules)
- `keepttl`: If there is a TTL already set on the key, retain that TTL instead of overwriting it

```
redis.set "foo", "bar", ex: 1
redis.get("foo") # => "bar"
sleep 1.second
redis.get("foo") # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Set a given key to a given value, optionally specifying time-to-live (TTL).
instance_methods.args_string: (key : String, value : String, ex = nil, px = nil, nx = false, xx = false, keepttl = false) : Nil

def.name: set

instance_methods.name: xadd
instance_methods.doc:
Append an entry with the specified data to the stream with the given `key`
and gives it the specified `id`. If the id is `"*"`, Redis will assign it
an id of the form `"#{Time.utc.to_unix_ms}-#{autoincrementing_index}"`.
If `maxlen` is provided, Redis will trim the stream to the specified
length. If `maxlen` is of the form `~ 1000`, Redis will trim it to
*approximately* that length, removing entries when it can do so
efficiently. This method returns the `id` that Redis stores.

```
redis.xadd "my-stream", "*", {"name" => "foo", "id" => UUID.random.to_s}
```
instance_methods.summary: Append an entry with the specified data to the stream with the given key and gives it the specified id.
instance_methods.args_string: (key : String, id : String, maxlen, data : Hash(String, String))

def.name: xadd
def.body:
command = Array(Value).new(initial_capacity: (data.size * 2) + 3)
(command << "xadd") << key
if maxlen
  (command << "maxlen") << maxlen
end
command << id
data.each do |key, value|
  (command << key) << value
end
run(command)

instance_methods.name: xadd
instance_methods.doc:
Append an entry with the specified data to the stream with the given `key`
and gives it the specified `id`. If the id is `"*"`, Redis will assign it
an id of the form `"#{Time.utc.to_unix_ms}-#{autoincrementing_index}"`.
If `maxlen` is provided, Redis will trim the stream to the specified
length. If `maxlen` is of the form `~ 1000`, Redis will trim it to
*approximately* that length, removing entries when it can do so
efficiently. This method returns the `id` that Redis stores.

```
redis.xadd "my-stream", "*", {"name" => "foo", "id" => UUID.random.to_s}
```
instance_methods.summary: Append an entry with the specified data to the stream with the given key and gives it the specified id.
instance_methods.args_string: (key : String, id : String, data : Hash(String, String))

def.name: xadd
def.body: xadd(key, id, maxlen: nil, data: data)

instance_methods.name: xadd
instance_methods.doc:
Append an entry with the specified data to the stream with the given `key`
and gives it the specified `id`. If the id is `"*"`, Redis will assign it
an id of the form `"#{Time.utc.to_unix_ms}-#{autoincrementing_index}"`.
If `maxlen` is provided, Redis will trim the stream to the specified
length. If `maxlen` is of the form `~ 1000`, Redis will trim it to
*approximately* that length, removing entries when it can do so
efficiently. This method returns the `id` that Redis stores.

```
redis.xadd "my-stream", "*", name: "foo", id: UUID.random.to_s
```
instance_methods.summary: Append an entry with the specified data to the stream with the given key and gives it the specified id.

def.name: xadd
def.body:
command = Array(Value).new(initial_capacity: (data.size * 2) + 5)
(command << "xadd") << key
if maxlen
  (command << "maxlen") << maxlen
end
command << id
data.each do |key, value|
  (command << key.to_s) << value
end
run(command)

instance_methods.name: xgroup
instance_methods.doc:
Run a Redis XGROUP subcommand for a given stream. See the [XGROUP command in the Redis documentation](https://redis.io/commands/xgroup) for more information.

```
redis.xgroup "DESTROY", "my-stream", "my-group"
```
instance_methods.summary: Run a Redis XGROUP subcommand for a given stream.

instance_methods.name: xgroup
instance_methods.doc:
Run a Redis XGROUP subcommand for a given stream. See the [XGROUP command in the Redis documentation](https://redis.io/commands/xgroup) for more information.

```
redis.xgroup "CREATE", "my-stream", "my-group", "0"
```
instance_methods.summary: Run a Redis XGROUP subcommand for a given stream.
instance_methods.args_string: (command : String, key : String, groupname : String, *args : String)

instance_methods.name: xlen
instance_methods.doc: Return the number of entries in the given stream
instance_methods.summary: Return the number of entries in the given stream

instance_methods.name: xrange
instance_methods.doc:
Return the entries in the given stream between the `start` and `end` ids.
If `count` is provided, Redis will return only that number of entries.
instance_methods.summary: Return the entries in the given stream between the start and end ids.
instance_methods.args_string: (key : String, start min, end max, count = nil)

def.name: xrange

instance_methods.name: xreadgroup
instance_methods.doc:
Execute an `XREADGROUP` command on the Redis server.

TODO: Make the return value of this command easier to work with. Nested
heterogeneous arrays aren't easy to work with.
instance_methods.summary: Execute an XREADGROUP command on the Redis server.
instance_methods.args_string: (group : String, consumer : String, count : String | Int | Nil = nil, streams : NamedTuple = NamedTuple.new)

def.name: xreadgroup
def.body:
command = Array(Value).new(initial_capacity: 7 + (streams.size * 2))
(((command << "xreadgroup") << "group") << group) << consumer
if count
  (command << "count") << count
end
command << "streams"
streams.each do |key, value|
  (command << key.to_s) << value
end
run(command)

types.name: Connection
types.doc: The connection wraps the TCP connection to the Redis server.
types.summary: The connection wraps the TCP connection to the Redis server.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
We receive all connection information in the URI.

SSL connections require specifying the `rediss://` scheme.
Password authentication uses the URI password.
DB selection uses the URI path.
constructors.summary: We receive all connection information in the URI.

instance_methods.name: close
instance_methods.doc: Close the connection to the server.
instance_methods.summary: Close the connection to the server.

instance_methods.name: flush
instance_methods.doc:
Flush the connection buffer and make sure we've sent everything to the
server.
instance_methods.summary: Flush the connection buffer and make sure we've sent everything to the server.

instance_methods.name: multi
instance_methods.doc:
Execute a transaction within the server. The transaction is automatically
committed at the end of the block or can be rolled back with
`Transaction#discard`. Transactions are also rolled back if an exception
is raised.

```
redis.multi do |redis|
  redis.set "foo", "bar"
  redis.incr "counter"
  raise "Oops!"
end

redis.get "foo" # => nil
redis.get "counter" # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Execute a transaction within the server.

def.name: multi
def.body:
txn = Transaction.new(self)
begin
  txn.start!
  yield txn
  if txn.discarded?
    [] of Value
  else
    txn.exec.as(Array)
  end
rescue ex
  txn.discard
  raise(ex)
end

instance_methods.name: pipeline
instance_methods.doc:
Execute a pipeline of commands. A pipeline sends all commands to the
server before reading any of the results.

```
redis.pipeline do |redis|
  redis.set "foo", "bar"
  redis.incr "counter"
end
```
instance_methods.summary: Execute a pipeline of commands.

def.name: pipeline
def.body:
pipeline = Pipeline.new(self)
error = nil
begin
  yield pipeline
rescue ex
  error = ex
end
@socket.flush
result = pipeline.commit
if error
  raise(error)
else
  result
end

instance_methods.name: read
instance_methods.doc: Read the next value from the server
instance_methods.summary: Read the next value from the server

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.doc:
Execute the given command and return the result from the server. Commands must be an `Enumerable`.

```
run({"set", "foo", "bar"})
```
instance_methods.summary: Execute the given command and return the result from the server.

def.name: subscribe
def.body:
subscription = Subscription.new(self)
encode({"subscribe"} + channels)
flush
yield subscription, self
subscription.call

types.name: Future
types.doc:
A `Redis::Future` is what pipelined commands return. They will be resolved
with the value of the command that spawned them.

instance_methods.name: resolve
instance_methods.doc: Resolves a Future with the supplied Redis::Value
instance_methods.summary: Resolves a Future with the supplied Redis::Value

instance_methods.name: value
instance_methods.doc:
Read the value contained in this Future after it is resolved. If this
method is called before the Future is resolved, it will raise a
`Redis::Future::NotResolved` exception.
instance_methods.summary: Read the value contained in this Future after it is resolved.

def.name: value
def.body:
if resolved?
  @value
else
  raise(NotResolved.new("Attempted to get the value of an unresolved Redis::Future"))
end

types.name: NotResolved
types.doc:
A `Redis::Future::NotResolved` is raised when attempting to access the
value of a `Future` that has not been resolved yet. For example, calling
`pipeline.get("my-key").value`.
types.summary: A Redis::Future::NotResolved is raised when attempting to access the value of a Future that has not been resolved yet.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc: Initialize a parser to read from the given IO
constructors.summary: Initialize a parser to read from the given IO

instance_methods.name: read
instance_methods.doc:
Read a `Redis::Value` from the parser's `IO`

Example:

```
io = IO::Memory.new
io << "$3\r\n"
io << "foo\r\n"
io.rewind

Parser.new(io).read # => "foo"
```
instance_methods.summary: Read a Redis::Value from the parser's IO

def.name: read
def.body:
case byte_marker = @io.read_byte
when ':'
  parse_int.tap do
    @io.skip(2)
  end
when '*'
  length = parse_int
  @io.skip(2)
  Array.new(length) do
    read
  end
when '$'
  length = parse_int
  @io.skip(2)
  if length >= 0
    bytes = Bytes.new(length)
    @io.read_fully(bytes)
    value = String.new(bytes)
    @io.skip(2)
    value
  end
when '+'
  @io.read_line
when '-'
  raise(@io.read_line)
when nil
  raise(IO::Error.new("Connection closed"))
else
  raise("Invalid byte marker: #{byte_marker.chr.inspect}")
end

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc: Wraps a connection so that our `run` and `commit` methods can execute against it.
constructors.summary: Wraps a connection so that our #run and #commit methods can execute against it.

instance_methods.name: commit
instance_methods.doc:
Read all of the return values from all of the commands we've sent to Redis
and resolve all `Redis::Future`s with them in the order they were sent.
instance_methods.summary: Read all of the return values from all of the commands we've sent to Redis and resolve all Redis::Futures with them in the order they were sent.

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.doc:
The `run` method is required by the `Commands` mixin. When you run a Redis
command, it gets pushed to the server via this method.
instance_methods.summary: The #run method is required by the Commands mixin.

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.doc:
Execute the given command and return the result from the server. Commands
must be an `Enumerable` and its `size` method must be re-entrant.

```
run({"set", "foo", "bar"})
```
instance_methods.summary: Execute the given command and return the result from the server.

types.name: Value
types.doc:
Values consumed and emitted by Redis can be strings, 64-bit integers, `nil`,
or an array of any of these types.
types.summary: Values consumed and emitted by Redis can be strings, 64-bit integers, nil, or an array of any of these types.
